name: Calculator
description:
Calculator app for alexa. 
Currently supports addition, subtraction, multiplication and division. Can also handle complex decimal calculations. 
It also keeps your current answer in context so that you can operate on it. 
If you need to check your calculations, it'll also read out the calculation history for you. Just say, "tell me the calculation history".
Sample Utterances:
For Addition - What's five point nine plus three; Add two point nine to the answer.
For Subtraction - What is five point nine minus three; Subtract two point nine from the answer.
For Multiplication - What is five point nine multiplied by three; Multiply two point nine by the answer.
For Division - What's five point nine divided by three; Divide the answer by two point nine.

Features coming soon:
- Nth power and Nth root
- Logarithmic operations 
- Trigonometric operations
- Saving answers to memory
- Power or e, power of 10, power of 2
- Degree and radian conversions
and many more!

name: Phone Finder
description:
Can't find one of your android devices? It is on silent? This skill saves you: your device will ring with full volume and vibrate. Supports all your android devices!

UPDATE: Phone Finder Premium is now available! You can get the premium experience: Add up to six devices, name them and search for them by name.

In the free version, you can add one device. Connect your phone or tablet and never worry about losing them again.
Simply install the additional helper app on your Android device. You can find it in the Google Play Store. It's real simple:
1. Search for "Phone Finder for Alexa" in the Play Store and install it
2. Start the Alexa Skill: "Alexa, open Phone Finder"
3. Ask Alexa to add a new device
4. Alexa tells you your personal PIN-code. It is also displayed in the Alexa App
5. Open the Android App. Enter your PIN code and press "Activate"
6. Your device status becomes "Active"
7. Done

To add an additional device, just repeat these steps. Now, you can ask any of your Alexas (on the same user account) to find your device. If your device is online, it will quickly start to ring loudly and vibrate.

You can just start the skill without any specific command:
"Alexa, open Phone Finder". Alexa will ask you whether you would like to add, remove or search for a device. Alternatively, you can start the skill with a more specific command.

DIRECT COMMANDS:

Search for device:
"Alexa, open Phone Finder and search for my phone"
"Alexa, ask Phone Finder to find my device"

Add a new device:
"Alexa, open Phone Finder and add a new device"

Remove an existing device:
"Alexa, start Phone Finder and remove my phone"


Ask for the PIN code:
"Alexa, ask Phone Finder for my code"
"Alexa, open Phone Finder and give me my PIN"
review: Great, usefull skill. Have had to use it a few times now, has worked every time.  No more misplacing my phone and looking for hours to find it.

name: Where's My Droid

Mood journal allows you to create one journal per day. You can tell mood journal how you feel using one word at a time. You can update an existing mood journal from any previous date as well as delete any old journals.

name: Any.do
description:
Get More Done with Any.do, the #1 To-do list, Calendar & Reminders App. Now works in perfect harmony with Amazon Alexa.

To get started, enable the Any.do Skill on Alexa, grant Lists read/write permissions and link to Any.do by creating a new account or signing-in to your existing account.

Once connected, your Alexa Shopping & To-do lists will be added as new lists to your Any.do account (at the moment, these are the only lists available on Alexa).
Then just say ‘Alexa, add birthday plans to my To-Do list’ or ‘Alexa, add tomatoes to my Shopping list’.
Your tasks will immediately sync to your Any.do account on mobile, desktop and tablet - so you’ll have it with you anytime, anywhere.

New to Any.do?
Visit https://www.any.do  to download the app and start getting more done!
If you have any questions or issues connecting Alexa with Any.do, please contact customers@any.do
review: Great skill, perfect companion to the Any.do app!

name: Rain sounds
description:
Rain sounds is a skill to help you relax with peaceful rain sounds

You can say:

"Alexa, open Rain sounds"
"Alexa, start Rain sounds"
"Alexa, launch Rain sounds"
review: Sounds good.

name: Copper Labs
description:
Copper is a wireless energy monitor that delivers real-time data from electric, gas and water meters so utilities can engage consumers with actionable insights that manage peak demand and accelerate energy efficiency.

Note: Copper hardware is required! Please contact info@copperlabs.com for information on availability in your area.
review: Easy on boarding and integration with two Copper Lab units in two different houses.

name: Mosaic
description:
Mosaic lets you do more things with your Alexa easily, from controlling Tesla, asking for commute, to triggering powerful workflows of many things. Mosaic supports Google Calendar, Fitbit, Nest, Philips Hue, Lifx, Jawbone, Withings, Automatic, Tesla, Rachio, Insteon, Weather, Commute, News and Ambient Sound, with many more to come.

Workflow Example:
Our "Good Morning" workflow can help you warm up the house, give you today's weather forecast, report your Tesla battery level and mile range, followed by a brief summary of your Google calendar events and commute time to work. 

Immediately enjoy predefined Mosaic workflows or customize your own with the devices and services you love. Whether it’s Good Morning, Chill out, or I am home - easily control your life with one simple command.

All these functionalities are also available by typing to Mosaic’s Chatbot on Facebook Messengers, Slack, and SMS. When talking is not convenient, typing also gets things done!

To get started,
First, enable the Mosaic Skill.
Second, create a Mosaic account at https://saymosaic.com 
Finally, just link your favorite devices and services and start enjoying our pre-defined Mosaic workflows or create your own.

A few popular commands from existing Mosaic users:
“Ask Mosaic to change the color to blue”
“Ask Mosaic to lock up Tesla”
“Ask Mosaic for calendar summary”
“Ask Mosaic to warm up the house”
“Ask Mosaic for Good Morning”
"Ask Mosaic to turn on living room"
"Ask Mosaic to play ambient sound"
"Ask Mosaic to read news"

More commands?
“Ask Mosaic to list commands”

Want to know more about the cool experiment inside Mosaic? Visit us at https://saymosaic.com
review: I used Mosaic to control and monitor Nest usage via Alexa and Facebook. Really nice user interface!

name: Tigo
description:
This skill can update you on the current power output of your solar array. You can also ask about the total, daily average and daily max energy for a period of time. Get a quick update from your system by asking for a system summary.

This skill requires a Tigo Energy account with access to a Tigo optimized solar array.

*Note, this skill provides only energy and power approximations. Please refer to a revenue grade meter for exact figures.
comment heading: Tigo for Monitoring a Residential PV System
review: I downloaded "Tigo" on my Amazon Echo Dot to monitor a solar system in Los Altos, CA. I am very impressed with the range of voice commands I can use with Alexa.  The accuracy of the energy production compared to what my Tigo account says is spot on! I can ask about season production or simply ask questions about Tigo Energy, Inc. or solar optimizers. So cool!

name: Quick Japanese
description:
Want to practice your Japanese? Need a quick translation? This skill is simple, fast and can translate entire phrases! Just open the skill, speak a word or phrase in English, and Alexa will say it back to you in Japanese. It's easy! 

Translation results are powered by Yandex.Translate. Visit http://translate.yandex.com/ for more information.

name: is Steam Down?
description: Instead of google searching, save 10 seconds of your life and just ask Alexa if Steam is down.  Ah, Future and it's conveniences!
review: Solid!

name: Assist Reminder
description:
Assist Reminder will help you remember where you have put any of your items. You can do this by telling Alexa to remember where you have put certain things. Then you can tell Alexa to remind you where you have put these things. For example, you could say, "Alexa, tell Assist Reminder I put my wallet on desk ". After which you can say "Alexa, ask Assist Reminder where is my wallet" and Alexa will tell you your wallet is on your desk. This is helpful for when you can not find your things, such as your badge, laptop, headphones, etc.
To get a list of all your reminders, please say "Alexa, ask Assist Reminder to list all".
If you don't need the reminders, please say "Alexa, ask Assist Reminder to clear".
review: Agree, says no reminders scheduled or " you have no reminders here". So i tell her to just set reminder? Then whats the point in THIS skill? lol

name: Phone Finder
description:
Can't find one of your android devices? It is on silent? This skill saves you: your device will ring with full volume and vibrate. Supports all your android devices!

UPDATE: Phone Finder Premium is now available! You can get the premium experience: Add up to six devices, name them and search for them by name.

In the free version, you can add one device. Connect your phone or tablet and never worry about losing them again.
Simply install the additional helper app on your Android device. You can find it in the Google Play Store. It's real simple:
1. Search for "Phone Finder for Alexa" in the Play Store and install it
2. Start the Alexa Skill: "Alexa, open Phone Finder"
3. Ask Alexa to add a new device
4. Alexa tells you your personal PIN-code. It is also displayed in the Alexa App
5. Open the Android App. Enter your PIN code and press "Activate"
6. Your device status becomes "Active"
7. Done

To add an additional device, just repeat these steps. Now, you can ask any of your Alexas (on the same user account) to find your device. If your device is online, it will quickly start to ring loudly and vibrate.

You can just start the skill without any specific command:
"Alexa, open Phone Finder". Alexa will ask you whether you would like to add, remove or search for a device. Alternatively, you can start the skill with a more specific command.

DIRECT COMMANDS:

Search for device:
"Alexa, open Phone Finder and search for my phone"
"Alexa, ask Phone Finder to find my device"

Add a new device:
"Alexa, open Phone Finder and add a new device"

Remove an existing device:
"Alexa, start Phone Finder and remove my phone"


Ask for the PIN code:
"Alexa, ask Phone Finder for my code"
"Alexa, open Phone Finder and give me my PIN"
review: Tried it once and worked fine

name: Nanny State
description: Kids often nag for screen time and parents always ask the same sorts of questions to make sure other necessary tasks have been accomplished first.  Now Alexa can take care of that same rote, frequently negative interaction.  Just say, "Alexa, ask Nanny State if I can have screen time."
comment heading: There's just no substitute for real parenting
review: Dev clearly does not have children. What's stopping the kid from saying yes to all questions just to get screen time? Better yet, what's stopping the kid from just turning on the TV? Alexa? I don't think so. Who's going to do quality control? "Did you do your HW?" "Yes" "Did you answer all questions? Let me see/check." Oh wait, you can't. Technology can make your life easier but in this case it just can't replace a real parent.

name: Time Tone
description:
The first active timer for Alexa! Instead of simply beeping at a predetermined time, this skill provides second and 10 second interval updates! Has two modes! One that great for motivating short, 5 minute tasks The other mode is great for providing white background noise with a gentle reminder of time!

There are two modes: 
Mode 1). A 5 minute long timer. Uses beeps to indicate individual seconds and speech for 10 second intervals. Can end at any point, at which it returns the amount of time elapsed.

Mode 2). An hour long soothing timer. Uses a soothing tick-tock water noise to indicate seconds and periodic thunder for every 10 second interval. Can end at any point, at which it returns the amount of time elapsed.
Mode two format is as follows: 
tick tock tick tock tick tock tick tock tick thunder.

To use, there are a variety of ways to activate each timer. The general schema is:

To Begin:
Alexa, ask time tone to play.   This defaults to the first mode.
Alexa, ask time tone for first.   Plays the first mode.

Alexa, ask time tone for second.   Plays the second mode.
Alexa, ask time tone for rain.   Plays the second mode.


To end (Ends timer and returns elapsed time):
Alexa, ask time tone to end.     
Alexa, ask time tone finish.

Disclaimer: Timer accuracy is dependent on a variety of factors, including network latency and reliability. Not meant for mission-critical/time sensitive tasks.

name: St. Patrick's Day Countdown
description: Tells the number of days until St. Patrick's Day. Just ask, "Alexa, open St. Patrick's Day Countdown."
review:
Its almost time..
Whale oil beef hooked!

name: Presidential Countdown
description: Need a countdown of how long until Donald J Trump's presidential term will last (if nothing cuts it short...). Use this skill to get a readout of the years, days, hours, and minutes remaining.
review: Always a bit of good news - someday he'll be gone!

name: Blaze Bot
description: Blaze bot lets you know if it's time to blaze in CST. (4:20 am/pm)
review: Repeats the something every time.

name: Phone Number Check
description:
the skill provides basic information about a 10 digit phone number in the United State:
1. type of call: land line, mobile, etc (if available)
2. carrier: if available
3. location: if available
review: 16 billion 146 million bla bla bla is not a valid number haha

name: Random Number
description: This skill will generate a random number between 1 and 100 for you.

name: hey yinz
description:
Ever wanted to talk like a born and raised Pittsburgher? Well, this app can help you practice. It will translate any phrase you say into Pittsburghese. Note: a phrase might not have a distinct Pittsburghese translate so you might just hear the same phrase repeated back to you. 
 
 After the skill replies, you can also ask Alexa to repeat or slow down the last translation.
review: This app doesn't have a ton of utility, however it is really entertaining for those who know about the Western PA dialect.

review: Awesome

name: stopwatch
description:
This skill provides a stopwatch for timing arbitrary things.

You just start a stopwatch, and then you can check the status of the watch, restart the watch, or stop it at any point. You can also pause and resume the watch, and it will track the running total duration.

In addition to the explicit commands (start, status, reset, stop, pause, resume), launching the app also acts as a shortcut for managing your watch. Launching the app with no watch will start a new watch, while launching it with a running watch will automatically return your status.

Past reviews have mentioned the verbosity; there is no way for me to improve this as Alexa skills must be invoked by name.

Apologies for the recent disruption, my hosting shut down on me while I was in the hospital. However, I've now moved to paid hosting, and added Pause/Restart!

(Also listed as time keeper, for now).
review:
This seems to be the best of the available stopwatch skills, which sadly isn't saying much. I really waffled about whether to give it 3 or 4 stars, and finally decided on 4 because I'll only have to remember 2 commands - launch and stop - and it will let me play music at the same time. That is what I need a stopwatch skill for.

- There is a lot of variation in the command format. For example, "Alexa, launch stopwatch" or "Alexa, start stopwatch" starts a new stopwatch if one isn't already running - otherwise it gives you the status of the one running. But "Alexa, status stopwatch" or "Alexa, stopwatch status" doesn't work. "Alexa, stop stopwatch" also produces the status but does NOT stop the stopwatch. You have to say "Alexa, ask stopwatch to stop" to actually end it. Is it really necessary to use such a roundabout format?

- For actually using it, pretty much count on having to say "Alexa, ask stopwatch to" (pause, resume, stop). The simpler "Alexa, launch stopwatch" will start it or give you the status.

- As others have said, this isn't a precision function. I just want to time how long I can pedal on the exercise bike, so a few seconds' variation won't make a difference to me. But if seconds matter to you, there isn't an Alexa skill that will meet your needs.

- More important to me, this runs in the background so I can have Alexa play music while I am on the exercise bike and still keep track of my time.

name: Noteboard
description: Noteboard helps you keep track of basic tasks, like feeding your pet, or running the dish washer.  You can use to keep track of your chores in a busy household, and ask it to tell you who has done what, and when.
comment heading: OK for dog or cat feeding note only.
review: This only works for feeding cat or dog and possibly something about dishes. You must say it exactically "Alexa, ask noteboard WHEN was the dog fed?" If yiu vary at all she will not understand. If you try to leave any other message she talks about dishes. Pretty funny but not helpful. Will use for dog feeding after teaching family the exact phrase. It could have been much more useful.

name: Blaze Bot
description: Blaze bot lets you know if it's time to blaze in CST. (4:20 am/pm)
review: Good job, way to reinvent  the wheel. This skill already exists, just say "Alexa, what time is it?"

name: Foundmi
description:
This skill lets you ring your foundmi tag if you're having trouble finding it and you are sure that it's lying somewhere around you because you can see that you're connected to it with the accompanying foundmi iOS/Android. You need to be logged into the accompanying foundmi app and have a valid foundmi tag paired with the app before expecting this feature to work. Also you need to use the foundmi hero name that you've used to pair up your tag. Typical foundmi tag hero names are  Superman, Batman, Spiderman, etc. There are around 24 of such foundmi tag flavors available in the foundmi store.

It also lets you find your phone by ringing it if you're signed in to the foundmi app.
review: It's a quick way for me to find my keys and phone in the morning.

name: Bike Share
description:
NOTE: Bike Share only currently supports Citibike in New York City. Stay tuned for support for more bike share systems across the country!

Bike Share allows you to quickly find the closest bike share station to your address with bikes available! Use it on the way out of the house in the morning to avoid walking to an empty station. If a station has less than 3 bikes available, Bike Share will also let you know  the next station that is more populated. 

First, you need to add the address where your Amazon Echo resides. Start by saying:
"Add an Address."

Alexa will prompt you, step by step, to add your address, starting with your house number. For example, if your address was 350 5th Avenue, 10118, when prompted for your house number, you would say "three fifty".

Next, Bike Share will ask for your street name. Using the above example address, you would say "fifth avenue".

Finally, Bike Share will ask for your zip code. In the above example, you would answer, "one zero one one eight".

Once saved, you can then ask at any time to find the closest bike. Just say: "find me a bike."
Alexa will remember your address indefinitely, so you'll never need to add an address again unless you move your Echo. 

If you need to change your address, just tell Bike Share: "change my address". Alexa will ask if you want to overwrite your current address; if you respond "yes", you will be given the chance to enter a new address.
review: This skill keeps me from going to a station without bikes
